tweet: And we're intent on continuing to improve these mechanisms over time. Though keep in mind that none of this would have existed had we not had 4 years of bitcoin experience to learn from. Imagine what will exist in 2025 with 17 years of btc/eth experience as a basis.

Ethereum's *gas schedule* is definitely evolving toward more resistance over time. There are other features that have nice negative feedback effects (eg. the fact that block time targeting now includes uncles means that a DoS that doubles uncle rates would drop capacity 10-15%)
None of the attacks ethereum has been so far have been of the type that would behave differently depending on the consensus algo.
I believe I took more shots at ethereum than at tezos in this article

Imagine if when Satoshi wrote the whitepaper he had five appendices on selfish mining attacks, 51% cartel attacks, attacks on the high-timestamp rejection mechanism, etc etc. Reading that you might think bitcoin is super-complex too.

If miners 51% attacked to revert three weeks of history, what blockchain do you think would *really* be considered canonical bitcoin a year from then? My money's on the original chain extended with a PoW hard fork.

And that's the end of my technical appendix to the first tweetstorm. Original thread is here https://medium.com/humanizing-the-singularity/2018-year-in-preview-the-future-of-cryptocurrency-b99110480ff0?asdfasdf … or as tweets here https://twitter.com/leashless/status/941501389687214081 … good night!

Now, last topic in this "do your homework lads" technical appendix. Monetary policy. Deflationarry currencies favor explorers, but they completely screw up the later operation of the societies they help start: that's why you can't buy cheese for bitcoins. Monetary policy.

Now, second thing. Let's talk about how much faith we are putting in crypto systems. Read this https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dual_EC_DRBG … This descrbes how the NSA compromised the National Institute of Standards and Technology, the thing that certifies ALL THE REST OF YOUR CRYPTO ALGOS, chaps.

It may be that i'm simply too distant from these Foundation type structures to know their problems, but at the end of the day, if I can use these tools without having to worry about how they are governed, that's good enough governance for me. We have failed in that in crypto.

So firstly I want to talk about The Foundation as a construct. So far, all of the Foundation type entities in the crypto space have underperformed. All of them. And there are Reasons, of course, but I want to draw a sharp comparison to Apache and Wikipedia which seem to work well

7/ The world will respect us much more if we are even handed, rather than one-sided in our # crypto bullishness. Newcomers will be braced for whatever bear market(s) lay ahead, and # nocoiners will have less dry powder to draw from.
6/ I encourage everyone who has been in # crypto for a while to properly educate those new to the space, sharing both the merits & risks of participation.
5/ I have no idea when or why the next # crypto bear market will come, nor how bad it will be, but I consider it near-inevitable.
4/ We’ve gone through a few iterations of boom/bust in # crypto, with the most recent coming in late 2013 when # bitcoin first crossed $1K, only to then lose > 80% of its value by Jan 2015.

3/ Such # crypto concern is short-term by nature, and “social bubbles” are to be expected. As @ CarlotaPrzPerez has so eloquently taught us, financial booms & busts are part & parcel of technological revolutions.
2/ My recent dourness around # crypto is a reaction to “social bubble” indicators I am witnessing, and driven by concern for the new entrants that are fed one-sided bouquets of enthusiasm.
1/ Some people have commented that I seem bearish on # crypto recently. To be clear, I’ve never felt more bullish about the long term prospects of this technology.
